(41) 137.June 21, 1941.TO BE KEPT UNDER LOCK AND KEY.It is requested that special care may be taken toensure the secrecy of this document.WAR CABINET.INFORMATION AND PROPAGANDA.BY direction of the Prime Minister, the attached Minute from lord Beaverbrook to the Prime Minister is circulated for consideration atthe meeting to be held on Monday evening the 23rd June.(Signed) E. E. BRIDGES,Secretary of the War Cabinet.Great George Street, S.W. 1,June 21, 1941.
THIS DOCUMENT IS THE PROPERTY OF HIS BRITANNIC MAJESTYJS GOVERNMENTSECRET.PRIME MINISTER,Your Personal Minute M.668/1.I now fulfil my obligation to give you an outline of my proposals for asettlement of government policy on propaganda : The Ministry of Information will discharge its functions with five mediumsunder its control :1. Films.2. B.B.C.3. INewspapers.4. Publications.5. Public speeches.With a view to providing the Ministry of Information with control of thesemediums.(1) All films of all Ministries will be handed over to the Ministry ofInformation, and the production and distribution of films will be under the Ministry of Information^ direction. The Films Sectionof the Ministry will have co-ordinating authority.(2) B.B.C. as heretofore under the Ministry of Information, but the Ministrymust take firm control and give editorial direction in future. Thatwill involve placing the news service under the control of journalistswho will " put the front page to bed."(3) All contact between newspapers and Government Departments to be conducted through the Ministry of Information. The public relationsbranches of the various Ministries must, in future, communicatethrough the Ministry. The Ministry will, however, have no authority or discretion over the statements of Ministers who are Members ofthe War Cabinet.(4) All publications other than Departmental publications will be handled by the Ministry of Information. The issue of directions to the public,even in propaganda form, will remain a responsibility of Departments.(5) All propaganda speaking in the country under the Ministry ofInformation, excluding money campaigns, and suchlike.The flow of news requires to be strengthened and the system needs change.The Service Ministries should send their Chiefs to the Ministry of Information,Brooking, Elliot and Peck. In future, the Ministry of Information becomes the propaganda battle-front, and the Service Ministries are to be regarded as thesupply.The Service Ministries will carry on their public relations through theMinistry of Information. The two Secretaries of State, the First Lord and theNaval, Air and Military Chiefs will, subject to their Departmental duties, beready to consult with the Ministry of Information in case of any difficulty aboutnews. If the Minister is not satisfied with decisions taken by the service ministries, whose decisions stand in the meanwhile, he can appeal to the Cabinet.It is the duty of the Minister himself to follow the news. He must keephimself informed.[22630] About the British Council, there are two choices : (a) It may pass under the Ministry of Information, or(&) The Foreign Office should assist the Ministry of Information in the division of its functions, the British Council giving up what isoutlined in this document and confining itself to cultural activities,entertainments, scholarships and systems of education.The Foreign Secretary to have absolute control of foreign policy on propaganda through his agent, Lockhart. The general directives of the foreign secretary must be accepted by the Minister. Within this limit, the executionof the policy will rest with the Ministry.As at present, the News Section of the Foreign Office to be at the Ministryof Information.The Ministry of Information to " root-hog or die."B.June 21, 1941.
